Headline: Founder & CEO at TFM Healthcare Services Pvt Ltd, Founder and Chief Carer at The Family Member - with a successful exit, Certified Trainer for Dementia Care
Comment:
This 10 min healthcare delivery is just the thing we are doing since last 2 years at The Society Clinic 

And our outcomes are

1) healthcare is 24*7 job so don't go for zepto or blinkit kind of approach of morning to night, it will dilute the purpose,

2) the thing one need in or below 10 mins is primary care or emergency care, when you need dressing or injection support for stone pain/dog bite you need it immediately. In case of emergency you just need right support before ambulance arrives

3) for any preventive need you need quality and right guidance and not the speed,

4) for doctor consultation physical delivery is all times not possible or practically possible, but you need right technology to have right doctor support

5) technology is enabler here and not the core because AI will not give injection or do dressing, you need quality people, but yes good technology or AI will smoothen the processes,

6) healthcare support is a combination of speed and quality plus personal touch, so everything is in 10 mins is practically a bad idea...

An experience is behind this because in last 2 years, we have 60+ emergencies in avg 4 mins, 4000+ doctor consultations on time and 30000+ nursing care day in day out at The Society Clinic

Headline: Building Ruâ€™ya- a Multi-Technology Single Pane of Glass platform for IT Operations
Comment:
Few of my observations:

1. Medicine Delivery has active players, but profitability is a myth. The SKU mix is complex, and full prescriptions are rarely available. If customers still need to step out to complete their purchase, the convenience breaks down.

2. Scheduled Drugs need prescriptions, but thereâ€™s no real gatekeeping. Anyone can upload a prescription, thereâ€™s little to no verification (last I used). In theory, even a kid could order sleeping pills. Plus, some essential drugs arenâ€™t deliverable, adding more friction.

3. Online doctor consults are broken. Diagnosis quality is hit or miss. Often, itâ€™s junior doctors and patients spam chats, making it impossible to justify doctor costs. It just becomes unsustainable.

4. Healthcare is inherently trust-based. When people are spending money on health, they choose trust not the apps. That's why hospitals and local practitioners still win.

Lastly, healthcare is largely a grey-area and practitioners do not want to loose that control.
processed_comment: few of my observations medicine delivery has active players but profitability is a myth the sku mix is complex and full prescriptions are rarely available if customers still need to step out to complete their purchase the convenience breaks down scheduled drugs need prescriptions but theres no real gatekeeping anyone can upload a prescription theres little to no verification last i used in theory even a kid could order sleeping pills plus some essential drugs arent deliverable adding more friction online doctor consults are broken diagnosis quality is hit or miss often its junior doctors and patients spam chats making it impossible to justify doctor costs it just becomes unsustainable healthcare is inherently trustbased when people are spending money on health they choose trust not the apps thats why hospitals and local practitioners still win lastly healthcare is largely a greyarea and practitioners do not want to loose that control

Headline: AVP â€“ Growth & Strategy | Healthcare Business Architect | GTM & Market Access | Productization of Services | Digital Health | CAC-LTV | Independent Consultant - Elder care & Primary Healthcare I Startup I Adult Vaccine
Comment:
Great points overall. 
However few changes can make huge impact.
1. a 3-hour sample collection (between 2-6pm) and 4- 6 hour report delivery can enhance care in acute infections like Dengue, Urine infections, prolonged cough.
2. a 30-min nurse visit (if priced right) could be a great opportunity even in Tier 1 cities, patients wait hours for basics like injections, catheter mgmt etc. 
3. Scheduled home care also has huge potential, like Swiggy Scheduled, not fast but predictable and trusted.

Headline: DocOnline|Former Entrepreneur (successfully sold my 1st HealthTech venture)
Comment:
Great breakdown. A few complementary thoughts that might be worth layering in:
â€¢ Care navigation â€“ Access is one part, but helping patients know what to do next is often where real value lies. Especially important in chronic and post-acute care.
â€¢ Clinical accountability at the last mile â€“ Whether itâ€™s a home nurse or a teleconsult, accountability and escalation protocols are often underdeveloped in speed-first models.
â€¢ Health data interoperability â€“ Without some form of continuity in records, faster care can actually increase risk. Building with safety nets matters more than timelines.

Headline: Consultant
Comment:
A 10-minute service might be fine for a simple issue, but itâ€™s risky if it becomes the norm for more complex cases. 

Health is multifaceted, and some problems require more than just a quick fix. They need deeper investigation, long-term care, and ongoing support. 

A quick diagnosis leading to Superficial treatment carries the risk of missing underlying issues due to lack of time or thorough examination. Plus, it could lead to a greater reliance on technology and less emphasis on the doctor-patient relationship, which is vital for trust and comprehensive care.

Though honestly, if you're seeing 10 startups a week doing this, do share â€” we've been building in this space and can barely count half that with any real traction.
- Letâ€™s not forget â€” no one â€œneededâ€ 10-min groceries either, until suddenly bananas became more urgent than broadband.

- Urban consumption has a way of turning absurdities into expectations.

- True, 90% of healthcare doesnâ€™t need speed. But for the 10% that does â€” emergency meds, critical blood tests, or that dreaded 7AM fasting sample â€” speed becomes habit-forming convenience.

-At Zet Health, weâ€™ve learned that trust is the baseline, not a differentiator. But speed isnâ€™t evil â€” it just needs solid infra: trained staff, reliable logistics, and clinical protocols.

-So before we throw speed-focused healthcare under the ambulance, letâ€™s remember â€” 10% of lives improved is still impact.

TL;DR:
 Trust matters.
 Speed helps.
 And no, weâ€™re not building â€œBlinkit for bandagesâ€â€¦
 But Rapido for phlebotomists? Why not.

Headline: Marketing Manager/ Content Creator/ Technical Writer at ariesobgynclinic.com
Comment:
I work in a health setup in a clinic run by a gynecologist. I manage the social media as well as write health articles  ( reviewed by the doctor). The clinic offers online consultation as well as direct physical  consultations at the clinic.
 I have realized that patients prefer  to consult online with a doctor who they know they can contact physically, if necessary. They can verify the authenticity and qualifications of the doctor. 
Online consultations with doctors who may not be as qualified or reliable as  mentioned on the website is not preferred. 
The clinic is doing quite well  online as well as offline.

This is a highly intellectual post among so much of cringe.
I am glad my feed has this.

We (India) chase the wrong goals while following trends...
A 'trend' like 10 min once solved some core problem - coriander, masalas, protection, party snacks, pizza, powerbank etc.

A 'trend' like smartification and adding smartness to devices once solved some core problem - being able to get more out of the device thru it's data output.

But, riding a trend bandwagon gets VC money is what I see... I am not seeing it getting converted into sustainable, strong businesses though.

Comment:
I was one of the first online diagnostic startups in 2017, so i understand this market well.
The problem with home blood collection is the Hematology and Infection tests which constitute the majority volume of the tests and need results in 2-3 hours max. 
The Established players are largely focusing on Biochemistry and other high value tests which are not that urgent, but all of them put together, barely cover 15-20% of the market. 
This is the real problem in Diagnostics.

Headline: Building Healcare: Helping wellness seekers achieve optimal health through integrative techniques | Psychologist 15+ years
Comment:
I enjoyed reading the post, and someone had to say it. Through my experience, I've learned that people don't want fast healthcare instead, they want accessible healthcare that actually works.

I've watched people chase quick fixes for months, only to find lasting change when they commit to longer-term relationships with practitioners who understand their patterns.

The real gaps I see:
-Finding the right practitioner, not just any available one
-Building trust over time, not rushing consultations
-Integrating mind-body approaches that require patience
-Creating continuity of care, not episodic band-aids

Speed optimizes for convenience. Healthcare optimizes for outcomes. The best healing happens when someone feels truly seen and understood - that takes time, not technology. 

What's your take on how investors can better evaluate healthcare startups beyond the "10-minute" metric? Dilip Kumar?

Headline: Building Zet Health - India's first 10-min healthcare platform
Comment:
Speed, when paired with expertise and trust, is a winning formula, especially in healthcare. We at Zet Health are building the same.  

In diagnostics, timing matters. A phlebotomist isnâ€™t just delivering a service; they enter your home, perform a skilled and precise procedure, ensure you are at ease, and transport the samples to the lab within the required time window.

Thatâ€™s what makes healthcare delivery fundamentally different from any other form of quick commerce.

There are genuine clinical scenarios like Arterial Blood Gas tests  where 10-minute collections are not a luxury, but a necessity.

When the quality, price, and trust remain consistent, but one option delivers faster the choice is clear. Consumers are evolving, and so are their expectations. Quick commerce is the new normal ! 

Dilip Kumar would love to connect and discuss more.
